Given the poor results of the Q4 for the PBC division, will this extended program that was announced in autumn be continued to hire additional client advisor in the PBC area?

Yes, this is something we want to expand, and we will add resources, whether it's exactly the number indicated at the time, we've monitored that very carefully. But it is absolutely clear that this is the focus and we continue to build that up.

Okay. Maybe, Joe, whenever you have to run. We release you. At this point in time I would like to hand over the moderator for telephone conference and let's see what questions we have in the orbit to join us. Maria, can I hand over to you?
Yes sir. The first question from the conference call is from Stuart Graham, Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Oh hello there. I had two very quick questions. The first one is on Level Three assets. You will give a sensitivity analysis of the unobservable parameters in report and account, and I think in '07 it was a delta of plus three and minus two billion. Could you tell us what the '08 figure is please?

And then, the second question is on provisions. Thank you, Hugo, for the extra disclosure. That's very useful on the loan book. If I understood you correctly, you were saying you didn't think provisions could be higher than a billion in '09. But if I take out the IAS39 impact in Q4 it was 400 million already in Q4 and annualizing that gives me 1.6. So what's going on in Q4 that I shouldn't be annualizing that figure and comparing that with your one billion possible run rate for '09, please? Thanks.

Stuart yeah, hi this is Stefan, I'll start to your question on Level Three assets, yeah. So this number by the way is still a work-in-progress, as I said, but expect around a billion plus/minus on top of the old numbers. That's kind of where it's coming in.
Okay, thanks.

Well, the loan loss provision is relatively simple. When we transferred the assets in the banking book, so we adjusted it, and because you hold them to maturity so you have to adjust them to the price that you believe it's feasible for maturity. We do not foresee this type of loan loss provisions on these assets for the year 2009. I personally think, if you want a number, so I think it's a loan loss provision number of 1.1 billion is probably a reasonable number for 2009.

But the Q4 provision was 591 and if I take out 185, for the IAS39, then that's giving me 400 for Q4. And I guess most people think the world is going to get worse, not better so annualizing Q4 would give me 1.6 not 1.1. Or is there something else other than the 185 that you've adjusted?

Well, that, all the stuff that we adjusted that you would recognize as loan loss provisions but which aren't really loan loss provisions or they had to do with equity underwriting and similar things. But the true run rate for the year was 750 million in loan loss provisions, which were comparable to what you saw last year.
Okay. Thank you, Stuart. Next please.
The next question is from Kian Abouhossein, JP Morgan. Please go ahead.

Yes, hi. On your IAS39 reclassification assets, could you tell me what's the mark-to-market unrealized markdowns would be if you would mark-to-market. And secondly, the details that Hugo provided were very useful, but if I look at your hedging losses of roughly four billion, about 20% of IB capital. And I look at your fluctuating losses at around 12 times your value at risk, I wonder how should I look at the risks that is in the IB going forward in a stress scenario that we had in the fourth quarter?
Yes, Hi, Kian. This is Stefan. On your re-class effects, we have on Page 28 of the handout, you'll see all the relevant numbers you need to know. Do you have that?
Yes. And is the mark to market in there as well?

Yes. And there's the P&L effect, there's the risk weighted asset effect. There is a loan loss provision effect and the asset effect. And there you will see that in the fourth quarter we reclassified with 11 billion much less assets than we did in Q3. And then you'll see their respective numbers.
Okay.

Kian, on your question about the risk in the investment banking and the instant trading. So let me start from the back. I think we all agree that VaR was never good in stress times. You know that VaR is calibrated over the last 360 days. It's benign. And it shoots only up once here in the middle of the crisis. So I think VaR level, I hope it never derives comfort in the bank from the VaR level that it just doesn't tell you the risk level. So therefore it's probably a debate that's not worth having. What really happened in investment bank is basically very simple.

So the prop loss is very easy to understand. So we had loan positions that were devalued and the loss is 1.4 billion as you can see from it. And that business has been largely shut down, so you've seen from the charts that Joe showed that this credit and equity prop rating has been de-risked by 90%. So, you can make your own numbers and you'll see that these events can not be repeated even on the worst circumstances. The second thing is, what happened really with credit trading and equity derivative trading. And again, it's a chart that is very important to understand that is when you look at Joe's presentation is the basis risk.

We all know that Deutsche Bank is a wholesaler, that means we produce financial instruments. These financial instruments on the one side of the balance sheets are always hedged with physical instruments, or an index on the other side. Where we had physical instruments let's say Euro to CDS that was hedged with the corporate bond on the other end, where we had that we were exposed to a type of risk that nobody else had faced in our life and which our models did not properly capture either, and I think that's true for most banks. That's the basis risk and the basis risk between cash and synthetic products went to over 300 basis points on average. In our example it wasn't that much, but that was the driver.

So what we have to do is in the fourth quarter we have to rapidly close that basis risk and we were actually successful but it took us a while to find counter parties who were willing to take that basis risk away from us and to close it. At this point in time it's about 80% closed. It's closed in a way that we can lift these hedges off of some of the – off of this basis should it come back in a favorable way even when the basis improves, at this point we haven't lifted anything. So, you can look at the bank where basis risk is much better controlled and much better managed then it was before.
But as I said though, Lard doesn't tell you the story now and didn't tell you the story before the blow-up of Lehman, and therefore we need to talk about what really happens in the bank.
Okay, can I just follow-up on one more question with nine weeks of the --
Very quickly, yes...
I still don't understand the mark-to-market of the reclassified assets because on Slide 29 --
Are you on page 28?
Yes.
The P&L number there is a difference, we had to show as profit the difference. As P&L effective difference between the IAS marking and the old marking and it's at 3.3 billion.
Okay.
That's the difference.
All right. Thank you.
Okay.
Thanks, Kian.
Thank, Kian.
In the interest of those on the telephone. In the meantime Joe Ackermann had to leave us but we are prepared to continue with the call and take your questions. Maria?
The next question is from Philipp Zieschang, UBS, please go ahead.

I have two questions. One is on asset wealth management and also the retail bank. I mean stripping out the underlying, or the one offs basically, the underlying result looks roughly breakeven for both of these divisions. Could you just comment how you see those develop going forward in a tough market environment? Whether Q4 was a particularly bad quarter, and whether there were other effects in there which drove the underlying result, that one?

And then the second question is just quickly on the – again on the Slide 28. You said that the mark ups basically left you with a positive revenue number. The footnote on the risk-weighted asset number, which says additional capital demand, am I right in assuming that basically it's 10% of the 3.2 billion is the additional capital hit? So, is it fair to say that the entire exercise, if I apply a tax rate of whatever, 30%, to the 3.3 billion pre-tax, and deduct the 10% of equity to be allocated to the risk-weighted asset growth, led to about a two billion increase in your common equity?

The last question is, of course, the – I can't follow exactly your math. But, of course, that's exactly this incentive, the IAS reclassifications have as you go on. If you look on Page 28 and you see the relationship between the October re-classes, the amount of it, and the risk-weighted asset charge that we had, and then as we moved on – our experience, that we are getting higher risk-weighted asset pressure on any re-class assets. That has something to do there, obviously, in the October ones where we certainly had the lower hanging fruit and now it will work through. So there is in this incentive, also by the way, as you've seen in the loan loss provisions, that obviously had increased as well and then we have to take, when we re-class this positions. So I only can say yes, it does drive up our capital need. And therefore you see also in our behavior already, why in Q4 that number was substantially lower.

Don't forget also that obviously the financial incentive was higher in the October re-classes because we had this going back to July 1 valuation, which definitely was positive on the P&L – on a going forward basis, if you re-class on the day of the reclassification, you're re-classing to current market value so there's is not this big impact anymore that was a result of this going back to July 1 valuations.

So overall, this re-class issue, I think it's – sometimes as I read some of the comments blown out of proportion, I think this would stay minimal. It is a tool that puts us at even playing field with U.S. GAAP at the end and that it makes both accounting standards more comparable. And again, we have put some strong rigor in it, Hugo also alluded to it that we don't want any assets here to be re-classed with intrinsic value is not correct. And to some extent, it's not positive and therefore to some extent, our view on this is that this is the most, the proper way on how to assess the value of these assets. It does not contain some of the market exaggerations that we saw on some of the assets. That's bottom line on what it is.

But underlying here, this is good credit quality, good underlying loans to good companies that are paying, that are well rated and so on. And so the mark-to-market valuation here was just really exaggerated. So that's how we look at it but you will see that as we move on, there might be just less volume. Also what I'd like you to contemplate, 36 billion of assets re-classified versus our total balance sheet size is certainly not a big number of re-classes.

On PBC, your question on the underlying, obviously that's a good question and that's obviously a core question that we have been asking ourselves. I think to take Q4, Q4 was just the worst of the storm. And to extrapolate now from Q4 numbers into a whole year, at least in our view, would be definitely exaggerating. There was obviously in PBC, the whole brokerage business dried out of course. If a storm like this occurs that creates a lot of customer uncertainty and we basically saw no customer, or very minimal customer activity. We were betting a little bit on that legislation, tax legislation change in Germany to see some more customer activity. But think about, if you even wanted to restructure, pre this tax change your portfolio, you would have had to take some losses in the worst quarter you could as a customer. And it was clear that not many customers went out and changed their portfolio and realized losses that they would have.

And in asset and wealth management, of course, we lack now the performance fees. The performances fees weren't there. We didn't have the performance that was expected. So most of this performances fees was performance fee-driven and they dry up. So we don't, and actually in our planning and our looking forward, we don't expect that Q4 is, in these businesses, in any way representative of the underlying business.
Have you seen a similar pick-up in the business at the start of the year, as Joe mentioned for the IB?
We would like to stay with the group statements but in general you see us positive about January.
Thanks.
Philip, thank you. Next please.
Next question is from Jon Peace, Nomura. Please go ahead.

Yes Good afternoon. I wondered if you could tell us what's your balance sheet exposure to emerging markets through loans and through other securities, and specifically would you just be able to break out your loans to Russia and to Poland. Thanks.
Can we get back with these detailed questions to you? I don't have these numbers available so...?
The simple fact is that we don't have the numbers here that tells you that the exposure isn't that big, so.
Okay, thanks.
John, we'll come back to you. Okay, next please.
The next question is from Huw van Steenis, Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Yeah good afternoon. In the investment bank in Q4 it looks like, from your very helpful disclosure, 100% of the underlying revenues actually was made by FX, money market and rates, if you take off some of the one-offs. I was just wondering to what extent do you think 2.3 billion in FX rates in money markets is a sort of sustainable number or was that just an outstanding quarter? Because it seems to be 2.5 times last year's. And then secondly, to what extent, as you go into January, have you started to have a slightly more balanced makeup, particularly with the tightening of credit in the investment bank? Thanks.

I think Joe showed in his chart where he is alluding to the mix of business that will have in our investment bank. He alluded to that's exactly the part of the business that we expect to see continuous growth. Now give and take some volatility but at the end, you know, the target, as you saw on this chart on how the new structure of the business will look like, that's the areas we expect to grow. So it was not a single aberration, we think that we will see continuous growth in these areas.
Okay, thanks.
Thank you HuwuH. Maybe we'll take one more from the telephone?
The next question is from Aurelia Ford, RBS.
Good afternoon. I would like to ask a question on basis risk. As far as I understand you haven't had write-backs on basis risk to say so in the fourth quarter. Am I correct?

Well, in the fourth quarter we put in the hedge to avoid further losses on basis risk and we haven't lifted that hedge yet. It has significant upside potential in this hedge, provided the basis risk drops to where it was before Lehman. But we aren't there yet and therefore it's completely premature to talk about the lifting of any these hedges.
Thank you very much.
Thank you, and maybe we would like to go back to the auditorium here in Frankfurt. Are there any more questions you would like to – Stefan [Dresdner Kleinwort], maybe?

Yes. I would like to come back to the question of market risk control, where, I have to say, you provided a lot of very helpful information about your risks but, actually, still very little about this risk which, I guess, provided the near death experience in the fourth quarter. You said on the one hand side that you're aware that valued risk doesn't tell you much. At the same time you said that, when you were asked about capital allocation, that you're using risk-weighted assets which are using a value-at-risk driven measure of risk.

So, independent of what the Basel II or Basel III will tell you, given what you have experienced in the fourth quarter, where you have basically lost your value-at-risk every day, how are you going to approach this philosophically, culturally, in terms of changing your risk management on the market risk side? I guess there has to be some kind of reaction, and then probably a big scaling up of the risk capital that you hold for market risk, value-at-risk?

Well the – it's a little bit different. So we never manage the market risk with value-at-risk. That's a number we use for regulatory purposes. And if you go through the industry, there's broad consent that you can't manage market risk with value-at-risk, for the simple reason that it doesn't tell you the full truth. So it has two major shortcomings. So it has historic data, which don't tell you what the stresses actually are. And the second is a lot of that risk that we have diversifies away, so, therefore, as soon as the correlation goes to one so your actual numbers are quite, are much, much bigger than they are in this model.

So we never use that as the primary measurement. We use stress tests, and our entire economic capital is based on stress tests. The economic capital for market risk, for instance, was, in the month of December, somewhere between – I can't remember the exact number, 4.5 to 5 billion for market risk alone. That gives you a very different picture. And it's calibrated to a one-off event, where we say it can really be a very remote tail event, but it wasn't enough either. So, did we really expect that we will have basis risk of 300 basis points? We have used stress scenario in many, many areas and they were not sharp enough, so that will change.

Now our internal capital allocation, whilst we reported to the outside world as risk-weighted assets, it is actually based on our economic capital. It's not based on VaR. So the way that the regulatory VaR for market risk is so low, so we will never do that. So we have much, much higher capital in the investment bank, because it's based on our stressed scenario-based economic capital. We don't need to change it, but would we have to have sharper stress tests underlying our parameters for basis risk? The answer is yes.
Okay. I think I saw one more hand? Joachim again, yes.

Yes, I just would like to come back on the NPL and risk provision trends. You mentioned that you've somehow changed your loss-given-default assumptions for the monoline exposure. Have you done anything similar to the rest of your loan book? Have you changed your expected loss assumption? And I mean, you gave very good disclosure on the top assets in your loan book, but have you done a stress scenario and leverage what you get to?

Well you can't take for everything a stress scenario otherwise you get completely unrealistic numbers and what is then the stress scenario to use. So what we do we review these assumptions all the time and now under Basel II you have to look at your history all the time in order to gauge the number that's used for the regulatory process. And the – in every recession the recovery rates come down. You see that all the time, so you need to adjust them anyway. And I think our process will capture the lower recovery rates without needing additional stress tests.

Carsten Werle of Oppenheim [Sal. Oppenheim]. Question relating to the Asset and Wealth Management business. When we look at your net new money figures I think they're actually quite disappointing in Q4. It looks like that you had quite significant outflows in Germany particular on the asset management side and private wealth more outside Germany. What do you consider the reasons for this? And I'm also looking for what would you consider the remedy? I mean is there a risk that we see declining margins, because you have to make more contribution in terms of prices, etc.?

Well one of the things they did, so they moved money out of equity funds and stuff like and moved it in our deposits. So we saw a climate where people thought just, there's too much risk out there, let's go into the safety of deposits, so some have compensated like this. And others went even further and moved the money then into TBs directly.

And, to add to this, first of all there was a different development a little bit between Private Wealth Management and Asset Management. Asset Management is certainly stronger impacted by this. And in the position obviously only to clarify also the market value component is in there. It's not only customers leaving, but it's also the valuation of the portfolios which shows the downturn.
Andreas?

Yes. I have two risk management questions, if I may. The Asset and Wealth management, I would like to dig a little bit deeper in the 217 million REIT infrastructure asset investment write down. Is it really a one-off, is more to come? Because Hugo you were telling us that it was something you took for the fund management part, but which meant it didn't go to the fund. So I would like to dig deeper into if it is really done with or not? Second is on the capital, on the structure of your capital on Page 13, the 1.2 billion uplift in Tier 1 in the presentation. There is, part of it is full pension fund assumption changes. I would like to know how is the quality of this and what you have changed exactly? So is it coming back? Or is it really a ongoing issue?

Okay. On this impairment, this – the one big impairment in there, it issued at close this number, yes, that's a one-off. And that part of it is done with, but that's the problem of one-offs. They tend to come unexpectedly. So at the end, it's very difficult to say if we will have other one-offs, but this one in particular was taken care of. Now the pension fund issue. Again, I alluded to, under IFRS one of the big problems was comparing what you owe to your employees in terms of pension commitments versus what you – what the value you had against it, what the asset values against it, as you know. You then have a positive or a negative. Deutsche Bank has always had a policy, to be very conservatively funded and always be in a net-positive position so that the value of our assets is higher than the liabilities that we have to appease.

Now you know that, on the liability side, on the pension liability side, there's a lot of math that goes in that drives this number. Obviously it's certainly also the discount assumption on the one hand, it's a big impact on the other hand. It's also the age of human beings tends to increase as so on, that's a volatile number. And then on the other hand, market valuation of the assets is the other volatile, so on both sides of that calculation you have volatility. And that's why the old system in IFRS was to avoid an extreme P&L volatility for that component, was to provide this corridor system. So 10% plus, 10% minus of that volatility change you did not need to record for P&L as a gain or a loss. If it went above this 10% corridor you would have to take the hit but over the remaining life of that liability. So, which was not a big impact but had to take it and then continue on.

So IFRS always intended to take volatility out and kind of with all the developments it didn't quite work and therefore there is this other option, which was provided the same as option three, to which IFRS will finally migrate to, which is basically just to take the full impact but take it directly to OCI or take it directly to capital. So what for Deutsche Bank basically happened is we decided to make this accounting change, by the way which I had done previously years ago, yes and it basically all it does is it now moves the benefit, the current benefit we have to equity. Will this generate now volatility in terms of equity, yes, of course. Yes, as you know these parameters are highly driven by these calculations, it will.
Looking around for the last time. Any pressing questions we have missed. Maybe one, Andreas, the last question.

This is a very short question. I'm Andreas Weese from UniCredit. In Q3 conference call you gave the first indication for the incremental risk charge and I would be interested if the 50 billion increase in risk weighted assets by the end of 2011 is still valid?

Yes, we had no change to that number but again what has changed in the whole, is in this time we were discussing and there was a lot of question whether regulators would act quickly in changing systems and changing – I think what we have seen over the last couple of months and the last couple of weeks that everybody understands that currency and capital ratios, current systems are basically sufficient. We've seen a mind set change, it doesn't make sense, I think that's what we understand the regulators have concluded, is to change systems at this point in time and to kind of put even more pressure on banks and worsen the situation in the general norm. I think everybody in the first mode to react to something had a different view so to be honest we had more this feeling that if changes come they will come, certainly much more later than we did expect even a few months ago.

Well, on that note I would like to close this meeting. On behalf of all colleagues here at Deutsche Bank I would like to thank you very much for your interest in Deutsche and for joining the meeting and I wish you all a safe and pleasant journey home and for those returning to London, I wish you any sort of journey home. Thank you, bye-bye.
